Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1901

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1924, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

PIONEER RECREATION AND SOCIETY LIFE

WHAT ABOUT MEALS? DID YOU STAY WHEN NOT INVITED AFTERBEHAND? WHAT WAS THE INVITATION TO A MEAL USED TO TAKE POTLUCK USED? WAS THERE AN EXPECTED OFFERING?

THEY ESTABLISHED CHURCH SERVICES WHICH MEETING TIMES VARYED FROM 1907 TO 1924.

1. In the first few years, how many houses were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Always? Sometimes? Never?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Usually Sundays.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Invited without invitation.

That time of the day did you go? In the morning and spent the afternoon there? Or in the afternoon and spend the evening there? What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes, if husband and family were there as well (that is, was the invitation to a meal served when people had come unexpectedly? No, but you came to visit anyway).

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped by? A cup of tea and a cookie.

7. In the early years that you were here, were there many parties, what kind of parties were they? Describe.

Yes, we had parties at each other's homes and had sing-a-longs and games at Jane's home that were frequent in later years! Olive dates and dances were also frequent.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times—every two weeks once a week, once a month, etc.? Not to the homes not away to nearby local fields doing plowing and gathering. The whole family liked to go out gathering.

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned.

(Use back of page, or extra sheet if necessary)

For the Memorial Day of 1914 those who had been when veterans came would go around and hail as many as they could and we would go to the larger hall and entertain them talk any thing we had in the house for lunch. The ones who played the violin (I'll sit by) and we would have a good time and make new friends and these meetings would be and maybe we could have debates and talks by local farmers on subjects such as summer following and raised garden and how best the food can be grown and raised there.
